I think I get what you're saying here. Feminism is about women's rights, 
including LGBTQ women and women of color. (Laci seems to imply here that 
it's about more than that, which I don't know is technically correct, 
though these problems seem very related to feminism.)

feminist, and still be pro-gay rights, for racial equality--even for men's 
rights, I believe (circumcision, etc).
Being feminist doesn't mean that you have to be for women's rights only or 
even for women's rights first.

That being said, I do think that some of these other issues are related to 
feminist issues, for example, the fact that men can also benefit from 
breaking down traditional gender roles.

TJ is usually a somewhat amazing constructor of arguments, but on the 
subject of feminism, he's terrible. He seriously just rambles ineffectively 
throughout most of this video. With other videos, at least he thinks about 
what he says better and has some good points, but a lot of it is the some 
of the biggest nonsense I've ever heard. The best point made in this video 
is that Laci's video sometimes talked more about universal equality rather 
than specifically feminism, which REALLY wasn't worth a 20 minute analysis. 
What needed to be said should have taken 2 seconds - "2/3rds of Laci Greens 
points are really more egalitarian/humanitarian issues than feminist 
issues."

Also, the mocking is really obnoxious, like at 3:06 and 15:50 and 20:46, 
and only does a disservice to TJ's argument, demonstrating how solely based 
on emotion his objections to Laci Green are. 

Then I thought the whole section in which they tried to discredit Laci 
because she "takes herself too seriously" was just hysterically void of 
meaning. Is there really something inherently wrong with taking a serious 
subject seriously? She clearly jokes frequently in the video, so it's not 
even a true point anyway.

And biology and evolution is not strictly deterministic of the behavior of 
humans. It's definitely extremely influential, but you can't say with 
certainty that human behavior is strictly deterministic according to 
evolution - there is no science behind that. We are not biologically 
restricted from forming a government that represents women and men equally. 
Men are not biologically forced to rape women. A flat earther is more 
logical. 

Bringing up the "stick with tits" was extremely awkward. It is not a straw 
man to point out that that was sexist, TJ reduced her to a stick with 
distinctly feminine features and degraded her for being that. It was not 
only pathetically childish, but also pretty sexist.

This video really fails to address any of the broader arguments of Laci's 
video, and was pointless to record. It only serves to significantly lower 
my formerly high opinion of TJ. 

TJ is usually a great YouTube voice. I just don't understand why he focuses 
solely on what's wrong with feminism, rather than speaks for the broader 
problems feminism tries to solve. ﻿

+Magnesium Got 95% in my stats exam, wanted to take it further, but we're 
doing a module on algorithms instead (interesting, but not as good as stats 
IMO). So, I can safely say I'm good with statistics. Which stats are you 
looking at? Can you send the links? That would be helpful.

Okay. Let's look at the wage gap. Yes, women are more likely to take part 
time jobs. And they're less likely to have a highly paid job or managerial 
position. Have you ever stopped to think about cultural influences that may 
lead to these findings? Some women and men really want part time jobs or 
jobs with less status. And that's completely cool, and their choice. But 
some are conditioned into thinking they can't do a highly paid full time 
job. There's a lady I know who's now a doctor, but she was told at school 
she wasn't allowed to do maths, because she was a girl. Hell! Dorothy 
Hodgekin (Nobel prize for Chemistry) was banned from Chemistry lessons at 
school and wasn't allowed to attend certain lectures, because she was 
female. I know times have changed, and both my friend and Dorothy were 
determined enough to stand up to prejudice. But some people (I'm kind of 
talking generally here, it applies to racial prejudice as well) have these 
beliefs ingrained into them for so much of their life, it takes a powerful 
personality to question it. Girls are taught to be weaker and more 
accepting; they're more likely to be told off for small things as children, 
they're less likely to be pushed to achieve (I'll relate you to some 
psychological studies if you wish). Black kids are likely to be reported to 
the police for running to catch a bus. It's so sad that these attitudes 
don't just die away. I'm not trying to be accusatory, but the way you 
constantly question my ability to read or interpret data in your comment 
despite my evidence that I'm pretty damn great at maths, could show some of 
your own prejudice. Would you question a man so much if he'd just told you 
that he got 95% in his maths exams? "Do you understand how easy it is to 
skew data?" "Do you understand human fallibility?" etc etc. Think about 
that one.

+Daisy Matild  You completely missed my point. The fact that you believe 
the distorted facts that Laci presents means either two things:

(1) You are ignorant of the actual data, or
(2) Your ability to read the data is poor.

I chose option 2 for you -- because I was deliberately being an asshole, as 
I feel is warranted toward so many in your group.

So.. because we "know" you aren't a failure at math, I urge you to actually 
look at the data. How are you at statistics? Do you understand how easy it 
is to skew data by leaving data points out or adding irrelevant ones in?

Do you understand human fallibility? Human error? Do charts presented 
account for margins of error? Do you read the fine print of surveys which 
make broad claims based on a sample size of a representative of humans?

On, and on, and on, and on. Laci does not seem to account for dips in her 
data, that would give the impression that she is wrong.

For example, the issue of wage gap is: (1) not entirely true if you account 
for the exact same factors between men and women, and (2) where there is a 
supposed gap in wages personal, non-work-related choices made by women are 
not accounted for -- which are entirely dishonest things to leave out.

And then there is the issue of Laci using things that have little to 
nothing to do with feminism as reasons why feminism is important. It's like 
saying "Fat people exist, therefore feminism." It makes no sense.

Having said that, my objection does not mean I disagree with *everything* 
Laci has said or even her rationale for saying it.

On the point of gender wage gap, in the context of Canada (where I am 
from), there was a study done by the Canadian Labour Congress that 
investigated the reason why this gender wage gap exists. What they found 
was that most women are willing to take a lower paying job than men and 
that employers take advantage of this. This can be explained by gender 
roles by which men are expected to be the primary breadwinners and so have 
greater pressure on them to earn more. Therefore, men will be more 
selective than women who have far less pressure to be high wage earners. 
Interestingly enough, in male-dominated industries such as construction and 
resource extraction, there is little to no gender pay gap. However in 
female-dominated industries such as retail and the service industry, the 
gap is far larger. Anyone working in the retail/service industry would 
likely be earning a supplementary income, rather than be the primary 
breadwinner and therefore have less pressure on them to earn high wages. 
Men may be offered higher wages in these sectors as incentive to not 
migrate to higher-paying industries where they can likely earn more doing 
manual labour (albeit with less job security). So the issue doesn't seem to 
be as much to do with sexism, but more so with economics.﻿

Well, here's the thing about the arm-pit hair and it being a feminist 
symbol to have it unshaven. Shaven armpits became popular during the 1920s, 
a marked time in US history of female liberation. The decade was kicked off 
by the completion of the fight for women's suffrage through the passage of 
the 19th Amendment, a proud moment in US history to be sure. Women of the 
20s were sexually liberated as well, changing expectations of behaviors and 
social norms. Sleeveless dresses became an icon of a 20s woman and, because 
of the popularity of sleeveless dresses, shaven armpits became the style. 
Before that time, shaven armpits were unnecessary because a woman was 
expected to be covered at all times, if not stay at home. Her armpits would 
never be seen in public, so there was no need. The pioneering women of the 
20s changed that, paved the way for a liberation of female sexuality that 
hadn't been seen before in America, and changed all future generations.

So what I'm trying to was is that a shaven armpit isn't a symbol of male 
expectations of beauty imposed on a woman, it's a symbol of sexual 
liberation brought by the pioneering women of the 20s. An unshaven armpit, 
by contrast, is more indicative of a woman that was expected to stay at 
home or, if she does appear in public, stay covered in all ways.

What I'm also trying to say is that modern feminists and the feminists of 
the early women's movements or the second wave feminism of the 60s and 70s 
are far far far far far removed from each other and do not share a history. 
The feminists of the past should be forever remembered and praised... the 
feminists of today should be questioned and looked at critically.

+Nick Jaws I fail to see the difference between the 2. Consider that at the 
time the Suffrage Movement came about to give the right to vote to women, 
not all men had the right to vote. It was only ever given to land owners, 
which was not all men. For instance, civil workers like police officers and 
firefighters didn't have the right to vote, as they didn't own land.

But there was a way a man could have their right to vote: conscription. All 
able-bodied men were required to serve in the army, and only then were they 
privy to the right to vote (except for the too-young-to-vote crowd, who 
still were conscripted into the army during wartime nonetheless).

So when the Suffragettes came around, did they demand that the men not be 
required to fight in war and still retain their right to vote? Did they 
demand that ALL men and ALL women, regardless of occupation or class, be 
given the right to vote? Oh, no, don't be silly! They were so excited over 
equality, that Emmeline Pankhurst, one of the founding members of the 
Suffragettes, went all over the UK during WW1 to give speeches that tried 
to argue for conscription and for all men to fight for their nation. As 
well, many women's groups who also supported the Suffrage Movement at the 
time were involved in the White Feather campaign. You know, that one that 
called all men cowards if they weren't seen in uniform? That shamed them 
publicly by giving them a white feather if they were not out spilling their 
blood and guts on the battlefield? While women were exempt from combat 
altogether? Yet the women didn't have to fight and die to retain their 
rights like the men did, and the women's rights activists who demanded 
"equality" did nothing to stop the conscription or the forced ultimatum on 
them of "fight a war or have no vote". All they did was bitch and moan 
until they got what they wanted, much like as it's happening today.

Definition of true feminism.
"Feminism
The belief that women are and should be treated as potential intellectual 
equals and social equals to men. These people can be either male or female 
human beings, although the ideology is commonly (and perhaps falsely) 
associated mainly with women.

The basic idea of Feminism revolves around the principle that just because 
human bodies are designed to perform certain procreative functions, 
biological elements need not dictate intellectual and social functions, 
capabilities, and rights.

Feminism also, by its nature, embraces the belief that all people are 
entitled to freedom and liberty within reason--including equal civil 
rights--and that discrimination should not be made based on gender, sexual 
orientation, skin color, ethnicity, religion, culture, or lifestyle.

Feminists--and all persons interested in civil equality and 
intellectuality--are dedicated to fighting the ignorance that says people 
are controlled by and limited to their biology.
Feminism is the belief that all people are entitled to the same civil 
rights and liberties and can be intellectual equals regardless of gender. 
However, you should still hold the door for a feminist; this is known as 
respect or politeness and need have nothing whatever to do with gender 
discrimination."

Something important to note here, feminism wasn't inherently bigoted back 
in the times which are spoken of here. There were two primary groups which 
had differing opinions. Reconstruction was considered to have been the time 
where black men had gained equal rights. During the roughly 10 year period, 
black males' rights were the primary focus until the Bargain of 1877 ended 
the military districts and sent troops back to their barracks, stopping the 
enforcement of the Reconstruction Act. Feminists felt at the the time of 
black men had their time and that it was now womens' time to gain their own 
civil rights. Admittedly, they didn't understand what blacks were 
experiencing. There's a difference between blatant racism and not 
understanding what others are going through. Many feminists, like Emma 
Goldman, promoted much more open attitudes about things like homosexuality. 
It can be reasonably inferred from this evidence that, had they known of 
what blacks were going through, they'd have advocated for their rights too. 
Here's a general source for information on that time period, the actual 
book has far better details about first wave feminism and the events I've 
talked about:

http://www.wwnorton.com/college/history/give-me-liberty3-brief/ch/15/outline.aspx

There's a lot of excellent history here, I highly recommend reading it in 
your spare time. The details I've mentioned are in the actual book.

On top of all this, I have to say that there truly is a lack of 
understanding for what they're talking about with feminism. I'm all for 
criticizing it, but you should at least understand what the hell you're 
criticizing. There's a difference between understanding a viewpoint, and 
accepting a viewpoint. It's important to know that distinction.﻿

censorship board, so the issue here is whether censorship can affect 
society.

I say no, it can't.  We've had censorship in media since at least the dawn 
of radio and television, and I don't see people saying "go fudge yourself" 
more often than "go fuck yourself."  I do self-censor myself in certain 
situations, but that's more out of respect for people than indoctrination 
by censored media.

There are some people who disagree with me, and believe that censorship can 
affect society.  Tipper Gore, for example, wanted music to be censored 
because she believed uncensored music was causing society to degrade.  Jack 
Thompson believed that violence in the media was affecting children, and 
essentially wanted games to be "censored" by not having violent video games 
available.  Anita Sarkeesian is also in favor of a certain kind of 
censorship, mostly targeted toward what she identifies as sexist tropes. 
 The problem is, in the first two cases, there was insufficient evidence of 
this effect when the cases went to court, and there's enough evidence 
debunking Anita Sarkeesian's points to fill a library.  So it's pretty well 
established that media has little to no effect on society.

I'm going to make one exception on this just for completeness: propaganda. 
 Like when a news organization goes out of its way to distort the truth in 
order to favor one particular agenda.  This *can* affect a certain segment 
of society, though my belief on this is that it's just lighting a fire on a 
part of you that was already there, not twisting your view into something 
else.  And if this was what the MPAA was doing, I would agree 
whole-heartedly with you.  But the fact of the matter is they don't force 
movie producers to say "women can't have orgasm" or "lesbian sex is wrong" 
or anything like that.  In fact, there have been plenty of movies that show 
women enjoying sex (the first one that comes to mind, no pun intended, is 
Jerry McGuire), homosexual sex (Behind the Candelabra and Broke Back 
Mountain), etc.  While it's okay to say the MPAA is bigoted toward women, 
to say that they affect society is wrong.  If anything, the MPAA is 
affected by society.  To see that in action, just look at some older movies 
and how harsh the ratings were.  A Clockwork Orange was originally rated X, 
but now rated R because society has deemed what's in that movie as "more 
appropriate" for children.  Midnight Cowboy was also rated X but re-rated R 
in 1971, just two years after it's original release, with *zero* 
modifications to the film.  So society has influence in how the MPAA rates 
films.

+JoToCamovies  I don't see what you're trying to point out there, dumb ass. 
 Are you trying to say that the rating of a movie *is* the movie?  Because 
if you are, you went full dumb ass.  Otherwise, what I said is exactly 
right...the rating of the movie is how a *few* people see what happens in 
the movie within society, since the movie *is* a reflection of society. 
 Some of them feel very strongly that, for example, lesbian sex is more 
inappropriate for children than heterosexual sex.  They don't represent any 
significant portion of society, so you can't conclude that's how society 
sees it, and they don't even have to justify *why* they gave the movie the 
rating they did, further alienating themselves from society.  In short, you 
can be upset at the MPAA for giving homosexual sex a harsher rating than 
heterosexual sex, but it's *not* the fault of society.

Your "[they] influence everyone in the entire world" nonsense is just that. 
 NONSENSE.  First of all, the MPAA only rates movies in America.  They have 
no jurisdiction outside America, and further, rating a movie is *not* 
required for movies.  Most theaters will only play rated movies, but the 
rating process is entirely voluntary, a fact you would know if you actually 
knew anything about the MPAA ratings system.  Numerous independent films 
have been released in theaters without being submitting for ratings by the 
MPAA.

Secondly, most people in America *do* *not* *care* what a movie is rated, 
so the entire ratings system is meaningless other than to ego-stroke a 
group of people (the ratings board themselves).  You can see this by the 
fact that, when releasing on DVD/Blu-Ray, a lot of "raunchy" movies get 
released as un-cut, unrated versions.  And they sell better than the rated 
version.

Finally, the ratings board doesn't say "you can't show this movie."  They 
aren't capable of saying that.  All they say is "NC-17", or not suitable 
for anyone 17 or under.  If you were a film maker, and you sent them a 
hardcore pornographic film, that's the *worst* rating they could give it. 
 So this has nothing at all to do with society.  It's not a social issue 
that a few people are bigots.  It's just a reason to be against those 
people.  So shove it up your dumb ass.
